title: 1983 NSWRFL season
text:
The 1983 NSWRFL season was the 76th season of professional <a href="rugby%20league">rugby league</a> football in Australia. Fourteen teams competed for the <a href="J%20J%20Giltinan%20Shield">J J Giltinan Shield</a> and <a href="Winfield%20Cup">Winfield Cup</a> during the season, which culminated in a replay of the previous year's <a href="grand%20final">grand final</a> between the Parramatta and Manly-Warringah clubs. During the season, NSWRFL teams also competed for the <a href="1983%20KB%20Cup">1983 KB Cup</a>.
1983 was the final season in the <a href="New%20South%20Wales%20Rugby%20League%20premiership">New South Wales Rugby Football League premiership</a> for Sydney-based foundation club <a href="Newtown%20Jets">Newtown Jets</a>, and the first reduction in the number of teams in the competition since <a href="Sydney%20University%20Rugby%20League%20Football%20Club">Sydney University</a>’s departure at the end of the <a href="1937%20NSWRFL%20season">1937 NSWRFL season</a>. It was also the first season that was played with four-point <a href="Try%20%28rugby%29">tries</a>.
Season summary.
For the first time, the number of points awarded for scoring a try was raised from three to four. There was also the introduction of a handover if a team was caught in possession six times, which had the effect of killing the traditional <a href="scrum%20%28rugby%29">scrum</a> but attracted many new followers to a game that had seen attendances decline by fifty percent since the record year of 1968. To counter a lucrative illegal <a href="betting">betting</a> market, legal betting via <a href="FootyTAB">FootyTAB</a> was introduced and was a regarded as a success.
Twenty-six regular season rounds were played from February till August, resulting in a top five of Manly-Warringah, Parramatta, Canterbury-Bankstown, Balmain and St. George, who battled it out in the finals. <a href="Manly-Warringah%20Sea%20Eagles">Manly-Warringah</a> managed 23 wins from 28 matches in 1983 – at the time the most wins in a season by a club in NSWRFL premiership history alongside <a href="Parramatta%20Eels">Parramatta</a>’s 23 in 1982.
The 1983 season's <a href="Rothmans%20Medal">Rothmans Medal</a>list was Eastern Suburbs’ back, <a href="Michael%20Eden">Michael Eden</a> and the <a href="Dally%20M%20Award">Dally M Award</a> went to Western Suburbs’ half, <a href="Terry%20Lamb">Terry Lamb</a>. "<a href="Rugby%20League%20Week">Rugby League Week</a>" gave their player of the year award to Manly-Warringah winger, <a href="Phil%20Sigsworth">Phil Sigsworth</a>. This season the Cocal-Cola Coach-of-the-year award was voted for by the coaches in the League and was awarded to rookie coach <a href="Laurie%20Freier">Laurie Freier</a>.
This was also the last year in the first-grade competition for foundation club <a href="Newtown%20Jets">Newtown</a>, who were dropped at the season’s end.
Teams.
The lineup of teams remained unchanged from the previous season, with fourteen clubs competing in total, including six <a href="Sydney">Sydney</a>-based foundation teams, another six from Sydney, one from greater <a href="New%20South%20Wales">New South Wales</a> and one from the <a href="Australian%20Capital%20Territory">Australian Capital Territory</a>. It was the last season for the Newtown club.
Finals.
Grand Final.
Parramatta powered over Manly for the second year straight to claim their third successive title. The 18-6 win saw Brett Kenny claim a unique achievement in scoring two tries in three successive grand finals. Kenny opened the scoring and the Eels raced to a 10-0 lead after 13 minutes when Eric Grothe steamrolled burly Manly fullback Graham Eadie.
Parramatta 18 (Tries: Brett Kenny 2, Eric Grothe; Goals: Cronin 3)
defeated
Manly-Warringah 6 (Tries: Phil Sigsworth; Goals: Graham Eadie)
